awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of Open-Source Electron Beam Powder Bed Fusion Platform to Expand Advanced Manufacturing Research and Education
awd_abstract_narration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award supports the acquisition of a novel open-source electron beam powder bed fusion (EPBF) system.  As the first system of its kind in the US, this instrument will enable University of Texas El Paso (UTEP) investigators and a large network of collaborators to perform fundamental research in key areas of metal additive manufacturing—enabling new material systems and enhanced process understanding and control. This knowledge can lead to lighter, stronger, higher quality and more versatile materials and parts--enabling more fuel-efficient cars that can be produced at lower cost, minimally invasive medical instruments and implants, and advanced aircraft engines with higher efficiencies and significantly reduced emissions and fuel consumption. The instrumentation will also enhance training for the next generation advanced/smart manufacturing workforce through use in undergraduate research and education and K-12 outreach activities. The instrumentation will enrich outreach activities in regional middle and high schools, to recruit students from predominantly underrepresented Hispanic backgrounds to pursue STEM careers.
 
The instrumentation will enable researchers to gain insight into processing-structure-property links for the EPBF process and, together with the capability for novel scan strategies, will provide knowledge needed to fabricate complex materials such as refractory alloys, high strength aluminum alloys, Ni-Ti shape memory alloys and metal matrix ceramic composites.  The instrumentation’s process monitoring capabilities will enable researchers to gain fundamental insight into physically relevant process phenomena such as powder ejecta, powder charging and oxidation that can cause defects.  The instrumentation’s high temperature processing capabilities will enable researchers to better understand the intricacies of phase changes, defect formation, and microstructural evolution in relation to the thermal history during processing.  This will provide a foundation for advances in fabrication of materials that withstand  harsh conditions and the development of more durable and resilient smart parts and novel materials needed for energy, aerospace, defense, transportation and medicine.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.inst_name: University of Texas at El Paso
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS AT EL PASO

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Texas at El Paso

por.por_cntn:
The research team at the W.M. Keck Center for 3D Innovation, acquired an open-source Electron Beam Powder Bed Fusion (EB-PBF) system as part of this award.   The system purchased was the Freemelt ONE (Freemelt AB, M?lndal, Sweden).  This acquisition allowed the team to expand its understanding of the EB-PBF process and how this system, specifically, could be implemented in advanced manufacturing.  It facilitated vast opportunities for research and training.

Intellectual Merit:

1. Research Advancement: Unlike in many commercial EB-PBF systems, the open-source platform eliminated some of the parametric constraints of the EB-PBF process.  The ability to manipulate scanning strategies to the extent needed by researchers, offered a level of precision and control that was previously not accessible.  As a result, it helped the group push boundaries in advanced materials research for metal additive manufacturing.

2. Customization in Design: The open-source nature of the EB-PBF system allowed for customization and adaptability in the design of research experiments.  These focused primarily on parameter development for printing of Inconel 718. 

3. Publications: Two conference presentations were delivered on the research for material parameter development of Inconel 718.  These presentations were: 1) S. Tahsin, “Exploring the Capabilities of an Open-Source EB-PBF for In718 Production,” Southwest Emerging Technology Symposium, El Paso, TX, April 2023; 2) S. Tahsin, “Exploring IN718 Alloy Production with Bidirectional Raster and Stochastic Spot Melting Techniques using an Open-source Electron Beam Melting,” 34th Annual International Solid Freeform Fabrication Symposium, Austin, TX, August 2023.

Broader Impacts:

1. Training for Educational Needs: This platform emphasized hands-on training sessions for students and researchers to understand the fundamentals of EB-PBF systems as part of additive manufacturing (AM) courses at The University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP).  This allowed for a real-world understanding that bridges the gap between theoretical knowledge and practical applications.

2. Enhanced Potentials of EB-PBF systems: Having an open-source system expanded the EB-PBF systems' potential for advanced materials research of high-performance alloys and refractories with applications in the metal additive manufacturing industry.

3. Community Engagement: This has fostered the possibility of engagement for users and researchers by promoting future collaborations, knowledge sharing, and advancement in the metal additive manufacturing industry.

Conclusion:

In summary, acquiring the open-source EB-PBF machine proved to be a key step to expand research and development for advanced manufacturing and training. The small form factor of the system not only facilitated academic research but also provided an opportunity for increased engagement by empowering researchers in the metal additive manufacturing industry.


Last Modified: 11/28/2023
Modified by: Francisco Medina
